#Text=CHAPTER XIV
#Text=As I drove into the yard , a bare-headed old nigger with a game leg throwed down an armful of wood he was gathering and went limping up to the veranda as fast as he could .
#Text=He opened the door and bawled out , pointing to us , before he had it fairly open :
#Text=" O Marse WILLyum !

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=A little , bright , black-eyed old lady like a wren comes running out of the house , and chirps :

#Text= O Bud -- O my honey boy !

_	_	_	_

#Text= I reckon not , Miss Lucy , " says Bud raising himself up on the mattress as she runs up to the wagon , and trying to act like everything was all a joke .

column1: #Text=She was jest high enough to kiss him over the edge of the wagon box .
#Text=A worried-looking old gentleman come out the door , seen Bud and his mother kissing each other , and then says to the old nigger man :
#Text=" George , yo ' old fool , what do yo ' mean by shouting out like that ? "
#Text=" Marse Willyum -- " begins George , explaining .
#Text=" Shut up , " says the old gentleman , very quiet .
#Text=" Take the bay mare and go for Doctor Po'ter . "
#Text=Then he comes to the wagon and says :
#Text=" So they got yo ' , Bud ?
#Text=And the old lady , smiling and crying both to oncet , says , " God bless her brave boy . "
#Text=But the old gentleman looked mighty serious , and his worry settled into a frown between his eyes , and he turns to me and says :
#Text=" Yo ' must pardon us , sir , fo ' neglecting to thank yo ' sooner . "
#Text=I told him that would be all right , fur him not to worry none .
#Text=And him and me and Mandy , which was the nigger cook , got Bud into the house and into his bed .

#Text=And his mother gets that busy ordering Mandy and the old gentleman around , to get things and fix things , and make Bud as easy as she could , that you could see she was one of them kind of woman that gets a lot of satisfaction out of having some one sick to fuss over .
#Text=And after quite a while George gets back with Doctor Porter .
#Text=He sets Bud 's arm , and he locates the bullet in him , and he says he guesses he 'll do in a few weeks if nothing like blood poisoning nor gangrene nor inflammation sets in .
#Text=Only the doctor says he " reckons " instead of he " guesses , " which they all do down there .
#Text=And they all had them easy-going , wait-a-bit kind of voices , and did n't see no pertic'ler importance in their " r 's . "
#Text=It was n't that you could spell it no different when they talked , but it sounded different .
#Text=I eat my breakfast with the old gentleman , and then I took a sleep until time fur dinner .
#Text=They would n't hear of me leaving that night .
#Text=I fully intended to go on the next day , but before I knowed it I been there a couple of days , and have got very well acquainted with that fambly .
#Text=Well , that was a house divided agin itself .
#Text=Miss Lucy , she is awful favourable to all this nightrider business .
#Text=She spunks up and her eyes sparkles whenever she thinks about that there tobaccer trust .
#Text=She would of like to been a night-rider herself .
#Text=But the old man , he says law and order is the main pint .
#Text=What the country needs , he says , ai n't burning down tobaccer warehouses , and shooting your neighbours , and licking them with switches , fur no wrong done never righted another wrong .
#Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=But you were in the Ku Klux Klan yo'self ,  says Miss Lucy .
